s.text: Eventually, his forced resignations from the Truman and Eisenhower administrations led Rockefeller to turn to elective office as the one way of establishing an independent base.
"Nelson," said the patriarch, "whom are we trying to impress?"
"Nelson," said the patriarch, "whom are we trying to impress?"

What is most striking about The Life of Nelson A. Rockefeller: Worlds to Conquer 1908-1958 (the first of a projected two volumes), though, is that this duality--the push to achieve wed to a penchant for flamboyant failure; the ability to win a passionate following yet alienate the people who could keep him in power--was evident well before he thought about running for public office.
To enemies, it refers to a legacy of bankrupt state government and failed social programs.
